Entries.default: The creature stares down at you with only dim recognition of your presence. Water drips down the tip of its mallet-like head.

<ispeech>So alone. Never alone. Is Ukaizo... breached?</ispeech>

A voice paws at your mind in a clumsy, unpracticed fashion. You feel something like the mental equivalent of a squint.
"What are you?"
"I have returned to Ukaizo, if that is what you mean."
[Attack] "Whatever you are, you're standing in my way."

<ispeech>We are the Gates of Ukaizo.</ispeech>

The construct rolls its gaze toward the city.

<ispeech>Return? Impossible. The old ones are dead.</ispeech>

The construct leans down to peer at you.

<ispeech>We guard the silence of Ukaizo. You are a disturbance.</ispeech>

Bronze plates grind together with a discordant shriek.
"This island is my people's birthright. I'm here to reclaim it."
[Attack] "I don't need your permission."

<ispeech>The silence of Ukaizo will be restored. Time will dismantle your bones.</ispeech>

Nodding, the construct attacks.
"Be that as it may, I'm not leaving."
<ispeech>There is nothing to inherit but bones and sorrow.</ispeech>

<ispeech>Ukaizo is closed. The Gates are barred.</ispeech>

A wave of heat emanates from the guardian.
"Before we settle this, I want answers about Ukaizo."

<ispeech>Our covenant with the old ones does not forbid questions.</ispeech>

The construct hesitates, its joints creaking.
"I didn't come to fight, but if you bar the way then I have little choice."
[Attack] "If the gates won't open, I'll tear them off their hinges."
<ispeech>You chose death when you set your bearing, traveler. Prepare yourself.</ispeech>
"So no one has been here since the devastation?"
Lunging forward, the construct attacks.

<ispeech>The chosen people of the Deadfire called Ukaizo home.</ispeech>

It stares off to the distance, fixating on one of Ukaizo's many spires.
<ispeech>The outsiders were their contemporaries. Full of wisdom, ingenuity, and terrifying ambition.</ispeech>
"That sure sounds like the Engwithans. Guess they got around."
<ispeech>The outsiders passed from the world. None of them remain.</ispeech>
"Not all of them passed. But we got the one they left behind."

<ispeech>Outsiders augured the doom of the old ones. The rift unmade them both.</ispeech>

A deep thrum of power echoes from somewhere beneath the construct's carapace.
"What caused the rift?"
<ispeech>None but the green colossus, whose every footstep disturbs tranquility.</ispeech>

"The Engwithans. Of course.

"Only they would create a monster and bind it to guarding their secrets."
"The Engwithans. They made you?"
<ispeech>They did not create us. They united us as one.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You? No, daughter of Amira. Us.</ispeech>
The construct fixes on Edér with a quiet mixture of irritation and curiosity. Finally it steers its focus back to you.
<ispeech>Now you know, and nothing you have learned can spare you from our obligation.</ispeech>
"And the Engwithans turned this thing against my ancestors?" Tekēhu touches the spot on his brow and shakes his head.
<ispeech>Necessary, son of Ngati.</ispeech>
"Enough of this. Let me through or die."
[Attack] "Your doom is long overdue, ancient one."
<ispeech>When the last screams of the old ones faded, only we remained.</ispeech>

<ispeech>The living were meant to forget Ukaizo. Nothing can be gained of remembering it.</ispeech>

Amid the general ire of the construct's thoughts, you feel a sharp jab delivered to your mind.

<ispeech>The son of Ngati deserves to carry truth to Berath's Wheel.</ispeech> 

The construct nods in Tekēhu's direction.
"What use is being an ancient guardian if you can't tell stories of the past?"
"If I rest my legs while we chat, it'll make for a better fight for us both."
[Attack] "You too will be forgotten in time, ancient one."
<ispeech>Your heritage is not ours to deny.</ispeech>
"I do not plan on joining my mother in the Beyond this day, ancient one." Tekēhu turns his gaze over to you and nods.
"I was under the impression that dragons loved to talk. Humor me."
<ispeech>We will... indulge ourselves before shredding your name from the long scroll of existence.</ispeech>
<ispeech>A challenge would be a welcome distraction. Take your reprieve, doomed one.</ispeech>
<ispeech>If a diversion is how you would spend your last moments in this life, so be it.</ispeech>
<ispeech>The old ones and the outsiders traded, collaborated, learned, and built together.</ispeech>
<ispeech>We are depleted of stories, trespasser.</ispeech>
<ispeech>By now you are rested, and there is little more to tell.</ispeech>
<ispeech>This... idle chatter was a refreshing change of pace.</ispeech>
<ispeech>May your journey through the Wheel be an informed one.</ispeech>
"Yeah, by a colossal god made of adra. Where have you been?"
<ispeech>Here. We have been here.</ispeech>
The Gates of Ukaizo regard you in disgruntled, calculating silence.

<ispeech>The outsiders coveted ancient Ukaizo. Its occupation was a hindrance.</ispeech>

The construct cranes its head around as if following the movement of passers-by.
<ispeech>Machines were built on a foundation of outsider lies.</ispeech>
"What were these machines?"
"Go on."
<ispeech>Ones which drew the spirits of the dead through a sieve.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Finally, the outsiders fashioned a guardian to stand vigil over their work.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Our bond with the old ones compelled us to trust their allies.</ispeech>
<ispeech>We were ordered to slam shut the Gates of Ukaizo for all time.</ispeech>
"What happened when the machines went active?"
<ispeech>The outsiders vanished from the world, leaving the old ones dumbfounded.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Quiet gave way to chaos. Storms battered the seas. The sleeping hearts of mountains awoke with fury.</ispeech>
"You were complicit in the death of my ancestors. Justice comes for you, creature."
<ispeech>Your principles do you credit, but you have sailed here to die.</ispeech>

<ispeech>When the machines were nearly done, the outsiders constructed bodies of flesh and bone.</ispeech>

Stretching its neck out, the construct mimics a height greater than its own.
"Bodies?"
<ispeech>Skeletons now, their remains littering great Ukaizo.</ispeech>
The construct stares on impassively, and then offers the slightest of shrugs.
"Tekēhu, what say we dismantle the creature that stood by and watched the downfall of the Huana?"
"Ekera, let it be so." Tekēhu narrows his eyes and squares his stance for a complex form.
<ispeech>You are the first kith to visit the shores of lost Ukaizo, and you will be the last.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Your lineage is far removed from this place, but this is home all the same.</ispeech>
Tell me or I will pry the knowledge from your mind.
<ispeech>Curious. The old ones had stalwart powers of concentration, but nothing like yours.</ispeech>
"I don't get the impression you intend to let me live, so where's the harm?"
<ispeech>If you desire is to spend your last precious seconds in idle chatter, we will not stop you.</ispeech>
<ispeech>We hope this puts your brilliant mind at ease.</ispeech>
"Whoa, that's, uh... Where would you even stab something like that?"
"What manner of creature is this?"
"Madiccho, is that some kind of... animat?"
"Ekera, and I thought I was the master of first impressions."
"Stay close, Ishi. That's one heavy bird."
"I'm not too proud to admit when I'm scared... terrified, actually."
"Aye. Sure. That. Whatever that be. Why not?"
The construct turns to the sound of speech, showing only dim awareness of the meaning. It swivels its head back around to face you.
<ispeech>They offered us a trade - eternal life for eternal service.</ispeech>
"I'm just trying to reach Eothas. He's the one you want."
<ispeech>Eothas has disturbed the bones of Ukaizo. The old pacts permit him to pass, but you will go no further.</ispeech>
"My people came from here long ago. Let me pass."
"I'm working with the Huana. This is their island."
"Give me access to the luminous adra and this can end peacefully."
"If you think I'm a disturbance wait until my friends arrive with their cannons."
"I'd really just here to claim anything of value that isn't nailed down."
<ispeech>We have heard the bellow of iron, smelled the explosions of powder. Your allies will sink beneath the waves.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Once, but no longer. The old ones forged the cornerstone of Ukaizo, but outsiders built around it.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Our kind protected the bones of the Deadfire before the first ships landed on Ukaizo. We do not surrender our vigil.</ispeech>
<ispeech>No. No one remains, no one returns.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You should have stayed away and treasured your life over gold and gems.</ispeech>
